Literature Review: The family Microviridae, comprising small single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) phages, has emerged as a dominant force in viral ecology, particularly in aquatic environments. This literature review explores the current understanding of microviruses, their diversity, abundance, and ecological significance, with a focus on the limitations of traditional approaches and the insights gained from recent metagenomic studies and isolation techniques.Historically, our understanding of microviruses has been largely based on the extensively studied phiX174, a model organism in molecular biology. However, recent research has revealed that phiX174 and its close relatives are not representative of the broader Microviridae family. Krupovic and Forterre (2011) proposed a revised taxonomy for Microviridae, introducing subfamilies such as Gokushovirinae and Bullavirinae, which has been crucial in recognizing the diversity within this family.Metagenomic studies have revolutionized our understanding of microviral abundance and diversity. Roux et al. (2012) conducted a comprehensive analysis of publicly available metagenomic datasets, revealing that microviruses are prevalent in various environments, particularly in marine ecosystems. Their findings challenged previous assumptions about the rarity of ssDNA viruses in nature, suggesting that methodological biases had led to underestimations of their abundance.The development of improved metagenomic techniques has been pivotal in uncovering the true extent of microviral diversity. Labonté and Suttle (2013) employed a novel approach combining multiple displacement amplification (MDA) with high-throughput sequencing to study ssDNA viruses in seawater. Their results indicated a much higher diversity of microviruses than previously recognized, with many novel lineages discovered.Host range and specificity are crucial aspects of microviral ecology. Zhong et al. (2015) investigated the host ranges of various Microviridae members, finding that some gokushoviruses exhibit broader host ranges than previously thought. This study highlighted the potential ecological importance of microviruses in shaping bacterial community structures.The evolution of microviruses has been a subject of intense research. Quaiser et al. (2015) conducted a comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of Microviridae, revealing complex evolutionary relationships and suggesting multiple instances of host switching throughout their history. This study underscored the dynamic nature of microviral evolution and their adaptability to different host environments.Recent advances in isolation techniques have allowed for the cultivation and characterization of previously unculturable microviruses. Krishnamurthy et al. (2016) successfully isolated and characterized several novel gokushoviruses, providing valuable insights into their genomic structure and potential host interactions. These isolates have expanded our understanding of microviral diversity beyond the well-studied phiX174 group.The ecological roles of microviruses have been increasingly recognized. Yoshida et al. (2018) demonstrated the significant impact of gokushoviruses on marine bacterial communities, suggesting their importance in nutrient cycling and bacterial population control in oceanic ecosystems. This study highlighted the need for further research into the ecological functions of diverse microviral lineages.Metagenomic analyses have also revealed the presence of microviruses in unexpected environments. Creasy et al. (2018) reported the discovery of novel Microviridae members in hot spring microbial mats, expanding our understanding of their environmental range and adaptability to extreme conditions.Despite these advances, challenges remain in studying microviruses. Kauffman et al. (2018) discussed the limitations of current metagenomic approaches in accurately quantifying ssDNA viruses, emphasizing the need for improved methodologies to assess their true abundance and diversity in natural environments.In conclusion, recent research has dramatically expanded our understanding of microviruses, revealing a world far beyond the well-studied phiX174. The true diversity, abundance, and ecological significance of these small ssDNA phages are only beginning to be understood. As isolation techniques and metagenomic methodologies continue to improve, we can expect further insights into the fascinating world of microviruses and their roles in diverse ecosystems.
